##  Ghezzi, Pietro Leone (1674-1755)

### Variant Names

———

### Dates

b. 28 June 1674, Rome

d. 6 March 1755, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * painter
  * draughtsman

### Biography

Pietro Leone Ghezzi, son of the noted painter Giuseppe Ghezzi, was an esteemed
Italian painter and draughstman working in Rome between about 1698 and his
death in 1755. Ghezzi was trained by his father in the Roman classical
tradition and his paintings could be found in both churches and private
collections throughout Rome, but his skill with portraiture and sense of humor
led him to become most famous as a caricaturist. In fact, Ghezzi is considered
to be the first professional caricaturist, producing thousands of drawings
throughout his lifetime.

The earliest of Ghezzi’s caricature drawings date from the late seventeenth
and early eighteenth centuries and mainly depict aristocrats, artists and
churchmen. Ghezzi moved among the upper-echelons of Roman society; his patrons
included Roman nobility, prominent clergymen, and French aristocrats living in
Rome (Pope Clement XI was a particularly important patron of Ghezzi). He was
therefore witness to the lives of the Roman elite, which he illustrated in his
many caricature drawings and etchings. Thus one valuable aspect of Ghezzi’s
work is its contribution to modern knowledge about less recorded aspects of
Roman society during this period.

Although Ghezzi was most known for his caricature drawings, at the beginning
of his career he also produced a number of religious paintings and frescoes
for various churches throughout Rome, as well as a large number of non-
caricatured prints, which depicted a range of subjects including archaeology
and theology. While Ghezzi’s caricatures are notable for the humor of the
facial expressions, expressed through bold contour lines, his other prints
show an attention to perspective and volume through shading and chiaroscuro.

Ghezzi led a prolific and illustrious career, and he earned many honors
throughout his lifetime. He was awarded the status of *Accademico di Merito*
at the *Accademia di San Luca* in 1705; he was named painter of the *Camera
Apsotolica* by Clement XI in 1708, a title which involved, among other duties,
the curation of the papal collections, the supervision of architectural sites,
and the decoration of buildings.

R. G-F.

### Sources

  * Bellini, Paolo. "Pier Leone Ghezzi." *Italian Masters of the Seventeenth Century*. New York: Abaris, 2005. 121-50. Print.
  * Ravasio, Raffaella Bentivoglio. “Ghezzi: (2) Pier Leone Ghezzi.” *Grove Art Online. Oxford Art Online*. 9 Dec. 2010. Web*
  * Lo Bianco, Anna. “Ghezzi, Pier Leone.” *Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani*. Vol. 53. Rome: Istituto della Enciclopedia Italiana, 1999. 682-689. Print.

#  Piranesi, Giovanni Battista (1720-1778)

### Variant Names

  * Piranesi, Giambattista

### Dates

b. 4 October 1720, Mogliano, near Mestre

d. 9 November 1778, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * draughtsman
  * engraver
  * architect

### Biography

Giovanni Battista Piranesi was an Italian draughtsman and engraver of
architectural views who worked in Venice, Naples and Rome during the
eighteenth century. He was the son of a master builder and his uncle, the
architect and engineer Matteo Lucchesi, was his first teacher. He trained with
the architect Giovanni Antonio Scalfarotto before continuing his studies in
architecture, painting and drawing under Giuseppe and Domenico Valeriano, who
were noted for their knowledge of perspective. Piranesi maintained a strong
interest in architecture and archaeology throughout his lifetime, and this
fascination helped shape the content of his prolific work as an engraver.

Piranesi moved to Rome in 1740, where he began to dedicate himself decisively
to the study of engraving. He apprenticed under one of the principle engravers
working in Rome, the Sicilian-born [Giuseppe Vasi](http://library.brown.edu/projects/rome/people/0105), who taught
Piranesi the fundamentals of intaglio techniques. Between 1743 and 1747,
Prianesi travelled around Italy, mainly in Naples and Venice, where he
encountered the work of painters such as Francesco Polanzani and Giovanni
Battista Tiepolo. During this period, Piranesi developed those conceptual and
pictorial elements, which included classical motifs, soaring perspectives, and
a skilled use of chiaroscuro, that came to distinguish his style of engraving.

In 1747, Piranesi permanently established himself in Rome and released his
first independent set of prints in the following year. He cemented his
position as one of the city’s foremost engravers with the publication of over
250 plates in [ _Le antichità Romane_
](http://library.brown.edu/find/Record/dc1126279548346484) (1748) In this
four-volume series, he illustrated the remnants of ancient buildings and
building techniques throughout Rome. Some of the views depict ruinous scenes,
along with an element of fantasy that was more pronounced in other works by
Piranesi, which included capricci, decorative views of architectural
fantasies.

Piranesi entered into the Greco-Roman debate of the eighteenth century, which
addressed the relative superiority of Greek and Roman architecture, with the
release of _Della magnificenza ed architettura dei Romani_ in 1761. In this
folio, Piranesi refuted the claim that Roman architecture derived from the
Greeks, asserting instead through a series of prints that the origin of Roman
architecture lay with the Etruscans. Additional books published by Piranesi
throughout the 1760s proclaimed the originality of the Etruscans, the genius
of Roman urban planning and the superiority of Roman architecture over that of
the Greeks. One of the most clearly polemical of Piranesi’s works was _Il
Campo Marzio dell’antica Roma_ (1762), which analyzed the remains of the
Campus Martius and was dedicated to Piranesi’s friend and colleague, Robert
Adam.

Adam was a Scottish designer who first witnessed Piranesi’s work when he
embarked on a grand tour from London and took up residence in Italy from 1754
to 1758. The two artists quickly developed a close and productive friendship,
and Piranesi came to consider Adam an adept artistic colleague. Meanwhile,
Piranesi’s work had a profound influence on Adam, whose stay in Italy was
marked by a great deal of productivity and experimentation. His brother James
made the tour two years later, from 1760 to 1763, but was less interested in
Piranesi’s work and less productive during his stay than his brother had been.
Adam returned to London with a style highly influenced by Piranesi, which left
its own impression on eighteenth-century British design.

During his career, Piranesi produced a tremendous output of over 1000 plates,
of which between 600 and 700 survive. These display both a technical
accomplishment and level realism, as well as innovation and a fantastical
dimension. Through the combination of antique themes with dramatic
compositions, Piranesi’s work both reinforced and challenged the Neoclassical
taste that took hold in Europe during the later eighteenth century. He was
made a member of the Order of Christ and named an Honorary Fellow of the
Society of Antiquarians in London in 1757, but the quality of his
draughtsmanship and ingenuity and the quantity of his engravings are the
biggest testaments to his illustrious career.

R. G-F.

### Sources

  * Kantor-Kazovsky, Lola. _Piranesi as Interpreter of Roman Architecture and the Origins of His Intellectual World_. Florence: L.S. Olschki, 2006. Print.
  * Lawrence, Sarah E. and John Wilton-Ely. _Piranesi as Designer_. New York: Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, Smithsonian Institution, 2007. Print.
  * Murray, Peter. _Piranesi and the Grandeur of Ancient Rome_. London: Thames and Hudson, 1971. Print.
  * Wendort, Richard. “Piranesi’s Double Ruin.” _Eighteenth-Century Studies_. 34.2 (2001): 161-180. Print.
  * Wilton-Ely, John. _Piranesi as Architect and Designer_. New York: Pierpont Morgan Library, 1993. Print.
  * Wilton-Ely, John. “Piranesi, Giovanni Battista [Giambattista].” _Grove Art Online. Oxford Art Online_. Web.
  * Wilton-Ely, John. _The Mind and Art of Giovanni Battista Piranesi_. London: Thames and Hudson, 1978. Print.

#  Polanzani, Francesco (1700-1783)

### Variant Names

  * Polanzani, Felice

### Dates

b. 1700, Noale, Venice

d. 1738, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * engraver

### Biography

Francesco Polanzani was an Italian engraver who worked first in Venice, near
his hometown of Noale, before moving to Rome around 1742. He specialized in
techniques of etching and engraving, and upon his arrival in Rome he became a
master carver at l’_Ospizio di San Michele_ a Ripa, an institution founded as
an orphanage with an adjacent school for apprenticeships. Shortly after
arriving in Rome, Polanzani established a working relationship with [Giovanni
Battista Piranesi](trp-0001), the master etcher, engraver and architect. One
of Polanzani’s most famous works is an etching of Piranesi, which was used as
the frontispiece for Piranesi’s book of engravings, _Antichità Romane_ (1756).
He is also well known for engraving a series of twenty-two plates depicting
the _Life of the Virgin_ based on drawings that are attributable either to the
French painter and draughtsman Nicolas Poussin (1594-1665), or to the French
painter and printmaker Jacques Stella (1596-1657). Polanzani also engraved
works by A. van Dyck, Carlo Cignani and Marco Benefiali.

R. G-F.

### Sources

  * Benezit, Emmanuel. “Polanzani, Francesco.” _Dictionary of Artists_. Vol. 11. Paris, Gründ: 2006. 156. Print.
  * Bryan, Michael. "Polanzani." _A Biographical and Critical Dictionary of Painters and Engravers, from the Revival of the Art under Cimabue ... to the Present Time: with the Ciphers, Monograms, and Marks, Used by Each Engraver_. Ed. George Stanley. London: H.G. Bohn, 1849. 586. Print.
  * Thieme, Ulrich and Felix Becker. “Polanzani.” _Allgemeines Lexikon der Bildenden Kunstler von der Antike bis zur Gegenwart_. Leipzig: W. Engelmann, 1907. 203. Print.

#  Bufalini, Leonardo (1486 or 1500-1552)

### Variant Names

———

### Dates

b. 1486 or 1500, Udine

d. c. 1552, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * engraver

### Biography

Leonardo Bufalini was a sixteenth-century engraver from Udine, who moved to
Rome together with his collaborator, the publisher Antonio Blado. There he
worked as a measurer, engineer and consultant for military architecture. Not
much is known about his life except for the information obtained from his will
and the short preface to his most famous work, a map of Rome printed in 1551.
This was the first comprehensive map of Rome since antiquity, and the first
ever printed map of the city. It comprised 24 sheets and measured 200 x 190
cm, and was the result of twenty years of study. Included in the woodcut was a
preface, a dedication to Pope Julius III, and a self-portrait dated 1551.
Bufalini had been working as a military engineer on certain projects, which
included the modernization of the fortifications of Rome, and the map was
partly a product of these engineering programs. The map is credited with being
significant as a representation of the urban fabric of a modern Rome, but
Bufalini created it with clear attention to antiquity. He depicts as whole
some ancient monuments that were in ruins and others that had completely
disappeared, thus blending together within a single map both the contemporary
and the ancient city. Bufalini’s map had a great influence on subsequent
representations of Rome. It served most notably as the basis for Giambattista
Nollis’ famous map of 1748. By July 1552, not long after the first printing of
his map, Bufalini had contracted some sort of illness, from which he died
shortly afterward in December of that year.

R. G-F.

### Sources

  * Maier, Jessica. “Mapping Past and Present: Leonardo Bufalini’s Plan of Rome.” _Imago Mundi_. Vol. 59. 2007. 1-23. Print.

#  Meyer, Cornelis (1629-1701)

### Variant Names

  * Meijer, Cornelis
  * Meyer, Cornelius

### Dates

b. 1629, Amsterdam

d. 1701, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * architect
  * engineer

### Biography

Cornelis Meyer was a Dutch architect and engineer who worked mainly in Rome
and is best known for his innovations in hydraulics. There is little
documentation of Meyer’s life in Amsterdam before he moved to Venice in 1674.
Venice was a popular destination for Dutch engineers seeking employment, and
it was there that Meyer first proposed hydraulic constructions as solutions to
problems with the rivers and harbors. Some of these proposals were adopted,
and Meyer eventually obtained the official title of engineer. However, before
any of his engineering plans were realized, Meyer left Venice in 1675 and went
to Rome, never returning to complete the projects that he had first proposed
to the Venetian government.

In Rome, Pope Clement X put Meyer in charge of a major civic project that
aimed to protect the Via Flaminia against the flooding of the Tiber river.
Meyer replaced the architect [Carlo Fontana](trp-0111) as head engineer of the
project because his plans were less expensive than those proposed by Fontana.
Since the Via Flaminia was the main road leading into Rome from the north,
through the Porta del Popolo, it was the route most used by pilgrims as they
entered the city. Therefore, it was critical to protect the road from the
periodic flooding of the nearby Tiber. Meyer constructed a _passonata_, a row
of piles, in the Tiber, which deflected the river’s current away from the Via
Flaminia. With this engineering feat, Meyer established himself among the
architects and engineers working in Rome during the seventeenth century.

After the success of the _passonata_, Pope Clement X hired Meyer to engineer
better navigation on the Tiber for the purpose of increased commerce. Meyer
came up with revolutionary solutions to expedite travel along the Tiber and,
with the help of artist [Gaspar van Wittel](trp-0010), he published his ideas
in a book entitled [ _L’arte di restituire a Roma la tralasciata navigatione
del suo Tevere_ ](http://library.brown.edu/find/Record/dc1126547990633751) in
1683.

_L’art di restituire_ was published in three parts and contained Meyer’s plans
for the Tiber River, illustrated with etchings of his own as well as those of
[iovanni Battista Falda](trp-0107), Gaspar van Wittel, [Jacques
Blondeau](trp-0014), Barend de Bailiu, and Balthasar Denner. The book was both
a record of Meyer’s engineering skills and feats as well as a form of visual
self-promotion for an engineer seeking further commissions. In addition to its
artistic quality and professional function, Meyer’s book indicated a new
engineering and architectural milieu that Rome had entered by the end of the
seventeenth century.

During his lifetime, Meyer published several other books including _Nuovi
Ritrovimenti_ (1689) and _L’arte di rendere i fiumi navigabili in varii modi,
con alter nuove inventioni a varii altri secreti, divisa in tre parte_ (1689).
However, it was with his designs in _L’arte di restituire_ that Meyer was able
to insinuate himself into the artistic and scientific elite in Rome. Upon his
death in 1701, he bequeathed his plans and projects in Rome to his son, Otto
Meyer.

R. G-F.

### Sources

  * Van Berkel, Klaas. “‘Cornelius Meijer inventor et fecit’: On the Representation of Science in Late Seventeenth-Century Rome.” _Merchants and Marvels: Commerce, Science, and Art in Early Modern Europe_. New York: Routledge, 2002. 277-296.

#  van Wittel, Gaspar (1653-1736)

### Variant Names

  * Vanvitelli, Gaspare
  * Occhiali, Gasparo degli

### Dates

b. 1653, Amersfoort, Utrecht

d. 13 September 173, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * painter
  * draughtsman

### Biography

Gaspar van Wittel was a Dutch painter and draughtsman, trained in his hometown
of Amersfoort, Netherlands in the workshop of the painter Matthias Withoos. He
followed in his master’s footsteps when he moved to Rome around 1675, where he
became known as Vanvitelli. He was primarily a painter of topographical views
(_vedute_). He began painting these views in the 1680s, and by the 1690s had
established a clear style, distinctive for its realism and subject matter.
While his predecessors in this genre had focused mainly on the ruins, ancient
monuments and religious cites around Rome, van Wittel sought to chronicle the
newer parts of the city, and so was a pioneer in the visual documentation of a
modern Rome.

Although van Wittel’s initial training was as a painter, and he spent most of
his career producing vedute of Rome, he was also an accomplished draughtsman.
When he first arrived in Rome, he worked for the hydraulic engineer [Cornelis
Meyer](trp-0006), who was working on projects involving roads, fountains and
waterways throughout the city. Van Wittel’s first work in Rome consisted of
fifty drawings, which illustrated plans by Meyer to restore navigability to a
stretch of the Tiber River. It was also during this period that van Wittel had
the opportunity to frequent the various printing studios throughout Rome, in
which he witnessed the printing of tourist guides to the city. This sparked
his interest in views of the modern city of Rome.

Gaspar van Wittel traveled extensively throughout Italy during his lifetime,
which resulted in a large number of paintings of cities throughout the
peninsula. He traveled to Naples at the turn of the century, but returned to
Rome after his benefactor, a Spanish viceroy, was lost in the revolution to
reclaim the city from Spanish rule. Van Wittel remained in Rome for the rest
of his life, being elected into the _Accademia di San Luca_ in 1711. His son,
Luigi Vanvitelli, became an established architect working primarily in Naples
and Rome.

R. G-F.

### Sources

  * Benezit, Emmanuel. “Vanvitelli.” _Dictionary of Artists_. Vol. 14. Paris: Gründ, 2006. Print.
  * Lüthy, Christoph. “Hockney’s Secret Knowledge, Vanvitelli’s Camera Obscura.” Early Science and Medicine (2005) 313-339. Print.

  * _Gaspare Vanvitelli e le origini del vedutismo_. Rome: Viviani arte, 2002. Print.
  * Briganti, Giuliano. _Gaspar van Wittel_. Milan: Electa, 1996. Print.
  * _Gaspar van Wittel e l'origine della veduta settecentesca_ Published Roma, U. Bozzi, 1966

#  Wouters, Gomar (1649 or 1658 - after 1696)

### Variant Names

———

### Dates

b. ca. 1649 or 1658, Antwerp

d. after 1696

### Occupation(s)

  * draughtsman
  * engraver

### Biography

Gomar Wouters was a Flemish draughtsman who was active mostly in Rome. No
paintings of his survive, but there are a number of engravings that depict
historical scenes and large views of Rome. His style of engraving is
identified as being influenced by the French printmaker and draughtsman
Jacques Callot, who was important in the development of the old master print.

R. G-F.

#  Blondeau, Jacques (1655-1698)

### Variant Names

  * Blondeau, Jacomo
  * Blondeau, Jano

### Dates

b. 1655, Antwerp

d. ca. 1698, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * engraver

### Biography

Jacques Blondeau was a Flemish engraver born in Antwerp, where he was trained
beginning in 1660 by the engraver Frederick Bouttat. He traveled to Paris in
1675, where he met the sculptor Bernini, who took him to Rome. Blondeau
specialized in engraving decorative works and paintings by masters of the
Roman school, such as those in the Palazzo Ricci and the Palazzo Doria-
Pamphili.

R. G-F.

## Fontana, Domenico (1543-1607)

### Variant Names

———

### Dates

b. 1543, Melide, Switzerland

d. 28 June 1607, Naples

### Occupation(s)

  * architect

### Biography

Domenico Fontana worked in Rome during the second half of the sixteenth
century as an architect and master builder. He moved to Rome from northern
Italy in 1563, attracted by the extensive building programs that were begun
during the Counter-Reformation period. He began his career as a plasterer
(_stuccatore_) during the early 1570s, and then as a mason and master builder
in 1574, with particular expertise in measuring and technical skills.

Fontana’s first architectural project was a villa in the Piazza Pasquino for
Cardinal Felice Peretti, constructed between 1577-78. In 1578, the cardinal
commissioned Fontana to build the Villa Montalto, a large estate the cardinal
planned as a way to develop the Esquiline Hill. Fontana acquired Roman
citizenship in 1585, the same year in which Cardinal Peretti was elected Pope
Sixtus V and in which Fontana was appointed papal architect. He also became a
member of the _Accademia di San Luca_ in that year. Fontana’s work as papal
architect included the renovation to varying degrees of the three papal
palaces (the Lateran, Quirinal, and Vatican palaces), as well as urban
planning projects, many of which were concentrated in the run-down quarters of
the city in order to encourage economic recovery in those areas. Fontana was
also responsible for increasing the accessibility of the major religious sites
in Rome, which resulted in a comprehensive street-building program. Part of
this program involved the re-erection of four Egyptian obelisks at certain
areas of importance throughout the city, and it is the transport and erection
of one of these obelisks for which Fontana is most famous.

Between April and September of 1586, Fontana orchestrated the transport of an
obelisk from the old site of the Circus of Nero, next to the basilica of St.
Peter’s, to its new home as a focal point at the center of the St. Peter’s
square. Fontana describes and illustrates this process in detail in a book of
his architectural feats and of the building projects of Pope Sixtus V, _Della
trasportatione dell’obelisco Vaticano et delle fabriche di nostro signore papa
Sisto V fatte dal cavalliere D.F. architetto di sua santità_, published in
Rome in 1590 (copied and republished in Niccola Zabaglia, [ _Castelli e
ponti…_ ](http://library.brown.edu/find/Record/dc1126611827544374)). For his
work on this project, Pope Sixtus V made Fontana _Cavaliere dello Speron
d’Oro_ and _Conte Palatino_, and conferred on him the status of Roman
patrician.

Accused of corruption at the beginning of the papacy of Clement VII (1592),
Fontana accepted an invitation to Naples by the Spanish viceroy, and lived
there intermittently until 1596, when he settled permanently in Naples. There
he held the title of _Ingegnere Maggiore del Regno di Napoli_ and published a
second edition of his book in 1604. After Fontana died in 1607, his workshop
passed into the hands of his brother Giovanni Fontana and nephew Carlo
Maderno, both of whom acted as supervisors of various projects designed by
Fontana.

R. G-F.

### Sources

  * Quast, Matthias. “Fontana (iv): (2) Domenico Fontana.” _Grove Art Online. Oxford Art Online_. 7 Mar. 2011. Web.
  * “Fontana, Domenico.” _Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani_. Vol. 48. Rome: Istituto della Enciclopedia Italiana, 1999. 638-643.

##  Vasi, Giuseppe (1710-1782)

### Variant Names

———

### Dates

b. 27 August 1710, Corleone, Sicily

d. 16 April 1782, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * engraver
  * painter

### Biography

Giuseppe Vasi was an Italian engraver and painter born and trained in Sicily.
He received a classical education in his hometown of Corleone and trained as a
printmaker in nearby Palermo, perhaps under the tutelage of the etchers
Antonino Bova and Francesco Cichè. He moved to Rome in 1736, already an
established printmaker, and spent most of his career documenting the urban
landscape of the city in engravings. Through his patron, the politically and
culturally influential Cardinal Troiano Acquaviva d’Aragona, Vasi met other
artists working in Rome, such as Sebastiano Conca, Ferdinando Fuga, and Luigi
Vanvitelli. He was also influenced by his predecessors, including Giovanni
Paolo Panini, Giovanni Battista Falda and Gaspar Vanvitelli, and by the
tradition of _vedutismo_ that these figures pioneered. During the early 1740s
Vasi also served as mentor to the young [Giovanni Battista
Piranesi](trp-0001), to whom he taught the technique of single-cut engraving.

Vasi’s output can be organized into two categories, the first being his
engravings of ephemeral structures, such as those used in the festival of the
Chinea, while the second and more well-known and widely disseminated were his
views of sites throughout Rome. Vasi’s first book, _Vedute del Tevere_
(1741-43), was a collection of these views. This book prefigured his later and
most well known work, _Della Magnificenze di Roma Antica e Moderna_ (1747-61),
a collection of 238 plates that was published in ten volumes. Vasi recorded
all types of architecture and organized these images of contemporary Rome by
subject, with each volume representing a different category of architecture.
This comprehensive project provides one of the most complete views of
eighteenth-century Rome. It acts as a pictorial supplement to Giovanni
Battista Nolli’s famous map of Rome, _Pianta Grande_, completed in 1748. Nolli
even supplied Vasi with measurements to aid in the drafting of his views of
the city. In 1765 Vasi created a large, panoramic view of Rome for King
Charles III of Spain, the _Prospetto dell’alma città di Roma_. The panorama,
which measures 102.5 x 261.5 cm, consists of 437 engraved plates and is
accompanied by several texts written by Vasi in the form of an _Itinerario_.

Over the course of his forty-six year career, Vasi established himself as one
of the principle engravers of Rome. In addition to his own great works, Vasi
collaborated with other printmakers such as [Philothèe-Francois
Duflos](trp-0106) and Louis-Joesph Le Lorrain, and through his workshop
contributed to such important books as Niccola Zabaglia’s 1743 [ _Castelli e
Ponti_ ](http://library.brown.edu/find/Record/dc1126611827544374) and Giuseppe
Bianchini’s _Evangeliario Quadruplex_ (1749). Through his extensive and
didactic body of work, Vasi illuminated the urban and architectural landscape
of eighteenth-century Rome, and through his relationships with patrons,
publishers, and other artists he left his mark on the print culture of the
city.

R. G-F.

### Biography

Philothée-Francois Duflos was a painter and etcher who came from a French
family of printmakers. He was the son of Claude Duflos and the brother of
Claude Augustin and Simon-Nicolas. He was awarded the Prix de Rome in 1729 and
spent 15 years living and working in the city. He was trained in Rome by the
painter and tapestry designer Jean-Francois de Troy, who was also from a
French family of artists. He mainly engraved _vedute_ of Rome, but is best
known for his a self-portrait that he painted for the Uffizi.

##  Falda, Giovanni Battista (1643-1678)

### Variant Names

———

### Dates

b. 7 Dec. 1643, Valduggia

d. 22 Aug. 1678, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * draughtsman

### Biography

Giovanni Battista Falda was an Italian draughtsman and printmaker who worked
in Rome at the end of the seventeenth century. He was apprenticed to the
painter Francesco Ferrari as a child and was mentored by Gianlorenzo Bernini
when he moved to Rome at the age of fourteen. His early work was noticed by
the printmaker and publisher Giovan Giacomo de Rossi, who took Falda on as an
apprentice at his print shop. Members of the de Rossi family were the
principal publishers of prints in Rome during the seventeenth century, and
almost all of Falda’s work was published at this shop. There, Falda learned
all the technical skills of engraving and etching, while also honing his
realistic, illustrative style of drawing. G.G. de Rossi also put Falda in
contact with emerging figures of the Roman art world, such as Francesco
Borromini and Pietro da Cortona. Falda finished his training at the age of 20,
subsequently beginning his career as a printmaker.

Falda’s main subject was the urban landscape of Rome, and he is best known for
his views, or _vedute_, of architecture throughout the city, especially those
renovation projects backed by Pope Alexander VII. In 1665, the de Rossi
printshop published a book of prints by Falda depicting elevations and
perspectival views of the construction and restoration projects sponsored by
the Pope, titled _Nuovo teatro delle Fabbricche, et edificii, in prospettive
di Roma moderna sotto il felice pontificato di n.s. Alessandro VII_. Most of
Falda’s engravings depict views of buildings, gardens, fountains, plans of
Rome, and representations of ceremonial events. Two of his most famous series
are the _Giardini di Roma_ (1670) and the _Fontane di Roma_ (1675).

Falda is a highly influential figure in the history of Roman printmaking for
several reasons. His realistic style of engraving was highly influential for
later Roman printmakers, such as Giovanni Francesco Ventunni, Alessandro
Specchi, and Giuseppe Vasi. The large number of architectural views that he
engraved (over three hundred) also contributed to Rome’s renown in the
seventeenth century for the _veduta_ as a genre of print. In addition, Falda
contributed to a new perception of the city of Rome itself , depicting in his
prints new images of the city, its palaces, churches and gardens. While
previous views of Rome focused primarily on the ancient city, Falda portrayed
a modern Rome according to an environment of urban expansion promoted by the
seventeenth-century Popes.

R. G-F.

Miguel de Sorello was a Spanish engraver active in Barcelona, Florence and

artists for Spanish and Italian artists, as well as devotional engravings. He

##  Fontana, Carlo (1638-1714)

### Variant Names

———

### Dates

b. 22 April 1638, Rancate, Italy

d. 16 February 1714, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * architect
  * engineer

### Biography

Carlo Fontana worked mainly as an architect during his long and illustrious
career, though he was also a proficient engineer, with particular expertise in
hydraulics. During the pontificate of Clement IX, he submitted plans to defend
the _Via Flaminia_ in the area near the Villa Giulia from periodic flooding of
the Tiber, a commission that was eventually given to [Cornelis
Meyer](trp-0006).

At the age of fifteen he began his training first as an apprentice under
Giovanni Maria Bolino, an architect and hydraulics engineer under Pope
Alexander VII. It was also around this time that Fontana moved to Rome from
his hometown in northern Lombardy, near Como. Upon completion of this first
apprenticeship, Bolino introduced Fontana to the architect Pietro de Cortona.
Fontana was already a skilled draughtsman by 1656, when he assisted Cortona in
a project to restore the facade of _Santa Maria della Pace_. The young
architect’s education continued under Gian Lorenzo Bernini, who employed
Fontana for about ten years, beginning around the time of the construction of
the _Piazza San Pietro_ (1656-1667). He concluded his training in the studio
of Carlo Rainaldi, where he worked for a period during the 1670s. Fontana
shared with Bernini an interest in the relationship between sculptural
elements and the urban environment, a concern that is evident in the design of
the great piazza at Vatican City. In addition, this initial work at St.
Peter’s in collaboration with Bernini led to future projects at the basilica.

One of these projects was the renovation of the baptismal chapel at St.
Peter’s. Fontana won this commission through a competition, along with his
collaborator Mattia De Rossi, who reported Fontana’s chagrin after the
rejection of the latter’s initial designs for the chapel. After the death of
De Rossi and the further rejection of Fontana’s designs, another collaborator
was assigned to the project, the Italian painter, draughtsman and printmaker
Carlo Maratti. Fontana never mentioned this partnership either in his book _Il
Tempio Vaticano_ or elsewhere.

It is also interesting in a discussion of Carlo Fontana’s ambitions to
consider his reappropriation of a set of engravings by Domenico Fontana, court
architect to Sixtus V in the late sixteenth century and only distantly related
to the family of Carlo Fontana. These prints memorialize an engineering feat
undertaken by Domenico in 1586, in which he transported an Egyptian obelisk
from beside St. Peter’s basilica to its current home at the center of St.
Peter’s square. Carlo redrew these engravings, which were reprinted in Niccolo
Zabaglia’s book Castelli e Ponti. Like Domenico, Carlo also wrote about his
own projects, publishing Il Tempio Vaticano in 1694.

Thus, although Carlo Fontana is widely considered to be one of the leading
architects of his lifetime, there were specific commissions, such as the
renovation project for St. Peter’s baptismal chapel, that he failed either to
win or to retain. Other projects, such as the redrawing and reprinting of
Domenico Fontana’s engravings in Niccolo Zabaglia’s _Castelli e Ponti_,
highlight to a greater extent the achievements of others. Fontana did earn
many honors throughout his lifetime, including his election into the
_Accademia di San Luca_ in 1667, where he served as president of the Academy
in 1686 and from 1693-99. Fontana lived and worked in Rome for most of his
lifetime, and despite various disappointments throughout his career, he was a
major contributor to the urban landscape of the city up through the early
1700s, until his death in 1714.

R. G-F.

##  Specchi, Alessandro (1668-1729)

### Variant Names

———

### Dates

b. 1668, Rome

d. 16 Nov. 1729, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * architecht
  * engraver

### Biography

Alessandro Specchi was an Italian architect and engraver who was born, trained
and employed in Rome. He studied architecture in the studio of [Carlo
Fontana](trp-0111), who was considered one of the leading architects of the
period. Specchi began producing architectural engravings in 1684, and many of
these sets of prints were published by Giacomo de’ Rossi and his son Domenico
de’ Rossi. Later on in the 1690s he engraved prints for treatises on
architecture. Among these were several books by Fontana, including _Tempio
Vaticano_ (1694) and _Ultissimo tratatto dell’acque correnti_ (1696), as well
as Giovanni Battista Falda’s _Il nuovo teatro delle fabbriche ed edificii in
prospettive di Roma moderna_ (1699). Specchi also engraved a series of 286
plates for _Studio d’architettura civile_ (1702-21), published by Domenico de’
Rossi, and this was the last of the engraving projects undertaken by Specchi.

Specchi was a successful working architect in his own right, his most
important work of urban architecture being the design for the _Porta di
Ripetta_. He submitted a model for a contest in 1703 and was awarded the
commission to design a docking area where the _Via Ripetta_ met the Tiber,
which would service the upper stretch of the river. Specchi’s plan took into
account the location of the port in an area of the Campus Martius that was
subject to frequent flooding, and made the port functional despite the
changing water level in that section of the river. This port was demolished at
the end of the nineteenth century and replaced with an embankment to better
protect the area from flooding. Specchi also assisted Carlo Fontana three
years later in the construction of the chapel of St. Fabian in _San Sebastiano
fuori le Mura_.

Since 1702, Specchi was a member of the _Congregazione dei Virtuosi al
Pantheon_, a small group of artists who met regularly at the Pantheon. In
1703, Pope Clement XI named him Architect of the _Tribunale delle Strade_. He
entered the _Accademia di San Luca_ in 1711 and was appointed architect to the
Fabric of St. Peter’s by Innocent XIII in 1721. Throughout his career, Specchi
continued to collaborate with Carlo Fontana on various projects, but developed
a distinctly Baroque style that deviated from his old master’s more
classicizing architecture.

R. G-F.

##  Zabaglia, Niccola (1664-1750)

### Variant Names

———

### Dates

b. 1664, Rome

d. 1750, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * engineer

### Biography

Niccola Zabaglia is an often overlooked but nevertheless important figure in
the history of architecture and in the development of construction and
restoration methods, especially with regard to the use of scaffolding. He was,
first and foremost, an engineer and mechanic, working in Rome devising systems
of hoisting and scaffolding to aid in the transport and restoration of
architectural sculpture and the maintenance of the fabric of the St. Peter’s
Basilica. Zabaglia was introduced to the field of building construction,
hoisting machines and scaffolds, early on when employed as a worker at St.
Peter’s. His career took off in 1696 when he engineered the transport of the
stone for St. Peter’s baptismal font, but his most important and innovative
projects involved the restoration of the Basilica during the 1730s. By this
time he had become the master mason of the Fabbrica of St. Peter’s, an
organization entrusted with the responsibility of building, restoring and
administering to the Basilica, and it was in this capacity that he oversaw the
restoration of friezes in the dome and stucco work in the nave of St. Peter’s.

Zabaglia worked with fully functioning, very detailed scale models of his
scaffolds and hoisting machines. These models attracted the attention of
Cardinals, among others, who wished to preserve them. Thus, the work that
Zabaglia completed as mechanic and supervisor of the projects for St. Peter’s,
the model and inventions that he devised, became the subject for a publication
sanctioned by Vatican officials, including Ludovico Sergardi and Lelio
Cosatti, entitled _Castelli e Ponti di Maestro Niccola Zabaglia_. Published in
1743, this book was meant to demonstrate the great intellectual and technical
assets at the Vatican’s disposal, the extent of the Church’s building
activity, and thereby to reinforce Christian doctrine. The volume contains
fifty-five plates that illustrate the structures, mechanisms and tools
invented, improved upon and used by Zabaglia. This work was so well-received,
and the engravings so detailed, that it became the essential manual for the
instruction of mechanics and the engineering of scaffolding, until the
twentieth century when new materials, specifically steel and tubular
scaffolding, gave rise to new building techniques. This popularity also
warranted a second printing of the book in 1817 and a second edition in 1824.

R. G-F.

#  Barbault, Jean (1718-1762)

### Variant Names

———

### Dates

b. 1 August 1718, Viarmes, France

d. May 1762, Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * painter
  * engraver
  * artist
  * printmaker
  * architect
  * landscapist

### Biography

Jean Barbault was a French painter and engraver best known for his capricci,
paintings of architectural fantasies, though he also engraved approximately
five hundred views of Rome throughout his lifetime. He trained under the
painter John Restout II (1692-1768) in Paris before, at the age of 29,
receiving a scholarship from the Académie des Beaux-Arts for travel to Rome,
where he lived and worked for most of the rest of his life. By 1748 he was
already established in a circle of Roman artists that included Paolo Anesi,
Jean-Laurent Legeay, Philothée-Francois Duflos, and [Giovanni Battista
Piranesi](trp-0001). In that year, he made engravings for Piranesi’s _Varie
vedute di Roma antica e moderna,_ four of which were later included in his [
*Recueil des plus beaux morceaux.*
](http://library.brown.edu/find/Record/dc1126529580812505) The next year he
was made a pensionnaire at the Académie de France in Rome, which was at that
time located at the Palazzo Mancini in the via del Corso. Barbault entered the
Academy without having passed the entrance exams, under the patronage of the
director Jean François de Troy, a French rococo painter and tapestry designer.
It was probably due to De Troy’s influence as well that he was admitted to the
literary _Académie des Arcades,_ joining the ranks of Noël Hallé, Jacques
François Joseph Saly and Charles-Michel-Ange Challe. However, he was excluded
from the Académie de France in 1753 having married (forbidden to
academicians), fallen into debt and out of favor with the new director of the
*Académie*.

Barbault collaborated with Piranesi again in 1756 on [ _Le antichità Romane_
](http://library.brown.edu/find/Record/dc1126279548346484), and this work led
him to produce a book of his own, [ _Les plus beaux monuments de Rome
ancienne_ ](http://library.brown.edu/find/Record/dc1126529580812505),
consisting of 128 plates drawn and partly engraved by Barbault. The
printmakers Etienne Giraud, [Freicenet](trp-0118), and [Domenico
Montagú](trp-0117) engraved the rest of the drawings, and the book was printed
by the publishing house of [Bouchard and Gravier](trp-0115) in 1761.
Barbault’s views of Rome are characterized by an emphasis on the public spaces
of the city, the piazzas and wide thoroughfares, which he depicts as vast
spaces with little human presence.

R. G-F. and R. G.

##  Lauro, Giacomo (1720-1778)

### Variant Names

  * Giacomo Lauri
  * Iacobus Laurus
  * Jacobus Laurus Romanus

### Dates

———

d. unknown.

### Occupation(s)

  * artist
  * printmaker
  * engraver
  * publisher

### Biography

Giacomo Lauro’s place and date of birth are unknown, although his signature
“Jacobus Laurus Romanus” seems to indicate that the artist was proudly born
Roman. His first documented appearance is on July 6th, 1583, when he received
medical attention at a barber shop. He was referred to in print as the
“intagliatore di rame romano,” or the Roman copper engraver, meaning he was
already practicing his trade at that point. Prior to that date, little is
known about him, but in the following year, 1594, he had a plate entitled
_Rocca Contrada_ published. Giacomo Lauro’s earliest patrons came from Poland
and commissioned battle scenes, which probably has important significance for
the dedications of the first two books of _Antiquae Urbis Splendor_, to King
Sigismund III of Poland and the Polish Duke of Savoy respectively.

Claudio Duchet (nephew of Antonio Lefréry, whose work greatly influenced
Lauro) published Lauro’s first major work, _Tiberio con la draga_, in 1585.
From that point onward, Lauro became quite prolific, specializing in
engravings of plants and views of the city. In 1599 and again in 1630, he
published a series of engravings of plants titled _Septum Urbis ecclesiae cum
earum reliquiis stationibus et indulgentiis._ Like most of the reconstructed
views of ancient Rome found in _Antiquae Urbis Splendor_, Lauro relied heavily
upon the works of other artists for the accuracy of his engravings of plants,
rather than first-hand research.

_Antiquae Urbis Splendor_ is frequently cited as his masterpiece, and indeed
became his life’s work as he continually added to it and released various
editions over the course of his lifetime. It is the work for which he is best
known. Penny Buckley writes, “It was meant, as Lauro proudly announced, to
recreate the physical remains of antiquity: its amphitheaters, circuses,
temples, and tombs, as well as its customs, especially those associated with
the emperor.” When the first edition was printed in 1612 with ninety-nine
engravings, he wrote that he had been working on the book for eighteen years
with the help of many instructors. The first edition was divided into two
books; a third book dedicated to Ranuccio Farnese was added in 1615 with 34
new engravings. Farnese became one of Lauro’s greatest supporters in the later
years of his career. The fourth and final book of _Antiquae Urbis Splendor_
was added in 1628, bringing the book to a total of 167 engravings. This was
not, however, the end of the book’s print history, with later editions
released in 1637 (curated by the Swiss Guard Giovanni Alto who also wrote a
preface, added an index, and numbered the engravings for the first time),
1641, and 1699 (which abandoned the 4 part nature of the book and instead
split it into two parts: antique and modern Rome). One particularly
interesting manifestation of the book was an edition released in 1625,
published by Andrea Fei in the year of the Jubilee in Rome. Because of the
large influx of visitors to the city, the book was reprinted with Italian,
French, and German translations to the Latin transcriptions on the reverse of
each page.

Throughout his life Lauro built up an impressive network of connections, as
evidenced by _Il libro amicorum_, or “The Album,” consisting of a series of
letters Lauro exchanged with dignitaries and other notable people between 1600
and 1636. The Album also provides biographical information about the elusive
artist, telling us that he had a wife and children, and lived for some time in
the district of Parione. His two sons were named Michael and ‘M. Gieronimo,’
and his daughter was a successful miniature portrait painter. He had another
daughter who passed away in 1600. Records show that Lauro was active until at
least 1645, when he published a series of engravings of plants and
descriptions of Italian cities. However, a letter of condolence to his son
Michael written in 1650 tells us that Lauro had already died by that time.

M. L.

### Sources

##  Bosio, Antonio (1575-1629)

### Variant Names

———

### Dates

b. Malta

d. Rome

### Occupation(s)

  * author

### Biography

Antonio Bosio was the founder of Christian archeology Rome and the first
scholar to apply the study of ancient Christian texts to a systematic
investigation of the Roman catacombs. Bosio was born in Malta in 1575. He was
the illegitimate child of Giovanni Ottone, a high officer of the Knights of
Malta, who was probably born in the northern Italian diocese of Ivrea. In
1587, twelve-year old Bosio was placed under his uncle Giacomo’s custody and
joined him in Rome. In the eternal city, Bosio’s uncle served as a
representative of the Knights of Malta before the Holy See. While living with
his uncle, Bosio studied literature and philosophy at the Jesuit _Collegio
Romano,_ and law at La Sapienza. Fully immersed in the cultural circles of
sixteenth-century Rome and influenced by the renewed interest in the early
Christian period, he began studying Church history and reading ancient
Christian texts.

Bosio can be better understood if placed in the context of Counter Reformation
Rome, where members of the new religious orders (especially the Oratorians and
the Jesuits), churchmen and lay intellectuals showed a keen enthusiasm for the
rediscovery of the early Christian past. In a time of intense religious
conflict with Protestants, they considered the history of the early Christian
community, with its heroic martyrs and its first popes, as evidence of the
continuous function/legitimacy of the Roman Catholic Church.

In 1578, the accidental rediscovery of an ancient Christian cemetery (at the
time believed to be Priscilla’s, but now known as the anonymous catacomb “di
via Anapo”) had bolstered people’s interest in Rome’s paleochristian past.
Bosio’s first direct exploration of a catacomb (Domitilla’s) happened on
December 10th 1593. At the time, he was an 18-year-old enthusiastic scholar of
Christian antiquities, animated by the desire to find important early
Christian inscriptions. After this first experience, Bosio started systematic
archeological exploration of the Roman catacombs (Tiburtina, Appia, Nomentana,
Salaria _vetus_ and _nova,_ Flaminia, Ostiense, Latina, and Portuense). He
discovered approximately thirty suburban cemeteries, pairing his active
investigation with his knowledge of written sources to interpret archeological
evidence. Bosio’s training was based on his broad reading of all available
documents on Christian antiquities, especially those related to early
Christian burial rituals and practices. He read the Greek and Latin Fathers,
conciliar documents and canons, papal epistles, ancient Christian chronicles,
and hagiographical collections.

In 1599, when Saint Cecilia’s body was found, Bosio published a history of her
martyrdom: _Historia passionis b. Caeciliae virginis, Valereriani, Tiburtii et
Maximi martyrum, nec non Urbani et Lucii pontificum et martyrum vitae._ After
1603, the year his father joined him in Rome, Bosio’s active exploration of
the catacombs seemed to have slowed down, as he began doing legal work for the
Knights of Malta. In 1604, Pope Clement VIII honored his research
accomplishments by officially legitimizing his birth. After 1608, Bosio
returned to his archeological activity and, according to his uncle Giacomo, it
was around this time that he conceived the idea of writing a complete history
of his explorations and of his discoveries. According to Bosio’s first plan, a
collection of illustrations was supposed to supplement the text. Bosio was
always aware of the necessity of visual images to reproduce and document his
findings. The painter Giovanni Angelo Santini (also known as “il Toccafondi”)
had accompanied Bosio on his first exploration. However at some point, Bosio
chose to replace him with the painter Santi Avanzino, whose paintings he
considered more accurate. Bosio hired Francesco Fulcaro to engrave Avanzino’s
paintings.

Bosio died in 1629, before he had the time to complete and publish the results
of his lifetime of research. He was 54 years old. He was buried in the Church
of San Biagio in Montecitorio. The Oratorian Giovanni Severano edited and
completed Bosio’s work, which was finally published five years after the
author’s death with the title _Roma sotterranea opera postuma di A. B.
romano._

A. F.

  * Ghilardi, Massimiliano. “Le catacombe di Roma dal Medioevo alla _Roma sotterranea_ di Antonio Bosio.” _Studi Romani._ XLIX (2001): 27-56. Print.

##  Labacco, Antonio (1495-1567)

### Variant Names

  * dall’Abacco, Antonio

### Dates

b. ca. 1495, near Vigevano

d. after 1567

### Occupation(s)

  * writer
  * engraver
  * architect

### Biography

Antonio Labacco was an Italian architect, engraver and writer. Originally from
Northern Italy, he moved to Rome at the beginning of the sixteenth century. He
began his training in the workshop of Donato Bramante, the Italian architect
most famous for his plan for the new St. Peter’s Basilica. Labacco continued
his career under the tutelage of Antonio da Sangallo, with whom he
collaborated on a number of projects, including the design of several churches
and the surveying of ancient buildings throughout the city. Having acquired
skills in surveying, design, and carpentry, in 1526 Labacco assisted da
Sangallo, Giuliano Leno, Pier Francesco da Viterbo and Michele Sanmicheli in
the refortifying of Parma and Piacenza.

Later, Labacco and his workshop began work on a large wooden model of da
Sangallo’s project for St. Peter’s, which he completed after six years in
1545. The following year, after the death of Antonio da Sangallo, Labacco was
fired by Michelangelo, the new head of the project for St. Peter’s. His large,
expensive model was rendered useless, but Labacco commemorated da Sangallo’s
plan with a series of large engravings that were printed and published between
1548 and 1549 by Antonio Salamanca and included in the _Speculum Romanae
Magnificentiae_.

This initial contact with Salamanca provided Labacco with experience in print
design and production, which proved fundamental in the realization of the
architect’s most famous work, the _Libro d’Antonio Labacco_. This
architectural treatise conveys Labacco’s admiration for the classical
architecture of ancient Rome. The plates, designed by Labacco and engraved by
his son Mario, depict reconstructions of ancient Roman monuments based on
information from written sources and Labacco’s own investigation of their
ruins. Originally printed in Rome at the workshop of Antonio Blado, the book
was well-received and reprinted several times up through the 1580s.

R. G-F.

##  Mascardi, Giacomo (1567-unknown)

### Variant Names

  * Iacobi Mascardi

### Dates

b. Bormio

d. unknown.

### Occupation(s)

  * printer

### Biography

Giacomo Mascardi was born in 1567 near Bormio. He made his living in Rome as a
printer, and became renowned posthumously for his relationship with the
Accademia dei Lincei and particularly for his role in printing the works of
Galileo Galilei. His nephew, Vitale Moscardi, continued to run the printshop
under the family name after Mascardi's death, and was the printer of
l'Accademia dei Lincei's most famous publication, _il Tesoro Messicano,_ in
1651.

##  Castelli, Pietro (1570-1662)

### Variant Names

  * Petrus Castellus

### Dates

b. Rome

d. unknown.

### Occupation(s)

  * author

### Biography

Pietro Castelli was born in Rome between 1570 and 1575. He studied botany and
medicine, which at the time were closely linked fields, at the Roman
university La Sapienza. 1594 he became a professor of botany and medicine at
La Sapienza, and was also the director of the Orto Botanico di Roma. In 1634,
he moved to Messina, where he was also involved with the cultivation and study
of the city botanical gardens. He was a prolific author on various topics from
zoology to chemistry, and although _Exactissima desriptio_ itself credits
Tobia Aldini as "auctore," it has been suggested that Castelli was the driving
force behind the publication of the catalog. That Castelli was the primary
author was indicated by contemporaries of the two prominent medical botanists
such as Allacci; furthermore, Mandosio who pointed out in 1692 that the poem
forming the dedication to the learned author not only mentions Castelli, but
actually comprises an acrostic spelling out "Petrus Castellus Romanus."
(Nocchi 419) While some sources assert that Castelli was the sole author of
the _Exactissima desriptio,_ and Castelli himself admitted later in his career
to publishing under others' names, Nocchi and Pellegrini suggest that this
work in particular required intimate knowledge and observations of the
flowering and growth patterns of the plants in the Farnese gardens, and
therefore could not have been written without the assistance its caretaker,
Aldini.

E. A.

### Sources

  * Castelli, Pietro, and Tobia Aldini. _Exactissima Descriptio Rariorum Quarundam Plantarum, Que Continentur Rome in Horto Farnesiano._ Romae: Typis Jacobi Mascardi, 1625. Print.

##  Ciamberlano, Luca (1570-unknown)

### Variant Names

———

### Dates

b. Urbino

d. unknown.

### Occupation(s)

  * engraver

### Biography

Luca Ciamberlano was born in Urbino sometime around 1570, although this date
is unconfirmed. Little is known about his early life, except that he initially
studied jurisprudence and law but subsequently abandoned his studies in favor
of pursuing a career as an engraver and printmaker. Currently the earliest
extant print attributed to him dates to 1599. His prints, and particularly his
frontispieces such as the one seen in _Exactissima Descriptio Rariorum
Quarundam Plantarum,_ are identifiable by their strong classical motifs and
composition and a strong grasp of shading and the depiction of human forms,
although his treatment of profiles and busts is often less considered.

## Pietro Castelli, Pietro and Tobia Aldini. *Exactissima Descriptio Rariorum Quarundam Plantarum, Que Continentur Rome in Horto Farnesiano*

The Aldini’s book is a singularly elegant example of 17th century Roman print
culture. The copy belonging to the Lownes Collection of the John Hay Library
remains in a contemporary leather binding with gilt decoration on the spine
and a red speckled foredge. It is larger than one might expect when looking at
the digital copy of the book, the cover having about the same dimensions as a
large laptop. The clarity and contrast of the black ink against delicate
cotton rag paper in the etchings is perhaps more striking than in the digital
version, and the impression of the type gives a sense of depth even to the
thin pages. The type appears in roughly size 24 point font in the body of the
introductory pages, and about 18 point in the main body of the text. The pages
have some yellowing around the edges and are slightly brittle, but in
remarkably good shape for an object that is nearly four hundred years old.
When held up to the light, the end-pages reveal elegant key-like watermarks.
The book was bequeathed to the John Hay Library in 1979 as part of the Albert
E. Lownes Collection of Significant Books in the History of Science, and
Lowne's personal bookplate pasted to the inside front cover indicates at least
the most recent provenance.

What is perhaps most notable about this book as a whole is the sense of
completeness and forethought one has when looking through the manuscript,
which is unusual for a book of this period. Many of the books in the Theater
that was Rome collection represent the vedute or specchi for the traveling
scholar, a form of manuscript that is far more fluid in form than this tightly
collated, highly consistent manuscript. The *Exactissima Descriptio* begins
much like the rest, with a formal declarative title page crediting Tobia
Aldini of Cesana as author, Odoardo Farnese as patron, and Iacobo Mascardi as
printer, with Luca Ciamberlano's initials below the frame indicating his role
as engraver. The dedication signed by Aldini follows, and then a dedication to
the Learned Author. It is at this point that Castelli is first mentioned, both
in the text of the poem and in the form of the acrostic. Various letters then
follow, from the printer to the reader, and to the Studios and Earnest
Botanists, and then the manuscript is formally endorsed ("with joy!") in the
imprimatur. This string of letters of dedication and affirmation are not
unusual for books of this period, but what follows represents a remarkable
show of attentiveness and organization; there is an index, naming each of the
sixteen chapters defined by their respective dedicated plants and including
page numbers. There is then an index of prints, also including page numbers.
The main body of the work then plays out, chronicling sixteen different types
of plant to be found in the Farnese gardens and their particular
historiography and use. The pages of prints also contain double-margins and
page numbers consistent with the rest of the book, indicating that each page
had been printed in a double run, once through the etching press and then
again through the letterpress, representing a remarkable investment of both
time and money, but also indicative of both assiduousness and thoroughness on
the part of the printer. The main body of the text is followed by three pages
dedicated to the amendment of errata typographica, followed by yet another
index in which the refinement of the typography is quite pronounced. The final
printed page contains a triumphant and somewhat stomach-turning list of the
diseases cured by remedies to be found in the book.

## Jean Barbault, *Recueïl des plus beaux morceaux de l'antiquité romaine qui existe encore* (1761) (A collection of the most beautiful morsels of Roman antiquity that still exist)

This book was printed in Rome, by Bouchard et Gravier (Libraires François rüe
du Cours près de Saint Marcel, de l'imprimerie de Komarek), in 1761. This is
Barbault’s first and most important work. It is, moreover, a first edition. It
could be understood as another version of Giovanni Battista Piranesi’s
*Antichità Romane* (1756). In 1756 Barbault was working on 14 plates for
volumes 2 and 3 of Piranesi’s *Antichità*, which led him to produce this book
a few years later. The Oxford Online dictionary describes the book as
containing “idealized Roman landscapes,” while the dealer description of a
similar book contained at Harvard’s Houghton Library describes the book as
containing “artistic renderings” of Rome’s ancient ruins. This is only
partially accurate, for the book could be roughly divided into two parts:
architectural and sculptural. The architectural portion of the book is
organized by building type: Temples (pl. 1-15), triumphal arches (pl. 16-21),
theaters (pl. 22-27), columns and obelisks (pl. 28-31), baths and aqueducts
(pl. 34-44) and tombs/altars (pl. 45-51). Plates 55-73 are devoted almost
entirely to ancient statuary (along with a few bas-reliefs), with no
historical or archaeological/architectural text accompanying them. Plates
86-87 take us outside Rome proper, featuring pictures and descriptions of
several recently discovered paintings from Herculaneum (along with an image of
the excavation site). Thus while the author prioritizes architecture, and
inscribes his work within the grand Roman vedute genre, the book itself
contains much more.

The book begins with a title page vignette depicting putti drawing and
measuring various Roman monuments from antiquity. Next there is an engraved
allegorical vignette, accompanying the dedication to “his Excellency, Jean
François Joseph de Rochechouart.” A description of each plate helps orient the
reader (now located at the back). A detailed examination of who drew and
engraved each plate is illuminating in terms of complicating the idea of
unitary authorship in the early modern era. The plates can be divided as
follows:

    Draughtsmen/Artists      Number of plates      
    
    Jean Barbault                       83                      
    Carlo Nolli                          1                      
    L. Rusalino/Bufalino                 1                      
    Unsigned                            43                     
    
    
    Engravers                 Number of Plates
    
    Jean Barbault                       56 
    Domenico Montagu                    52
    J. (Joseph?) Bouchard                6
    Freicenet                            4
    Unsigned                            10

Thus, while we attribute the book’s authorship to Jean Barbault, many other
artists had a hand in the book. Like many early modern books, it could more
accurately be conceived of as a collaboration, not a monograph. Domenico
Montagu looms particularly large, engraving roughly half as many of the plates
as Barbault himself. Indeed, many of the characteristically Barbault images,
which contain large picturesque and romantic ruins are attributable to
Montagu. In addition to the artists, the publishers Gravier and Bouchard also
appear to have a hand in this. It is the publishers who dedicated the book to
Jean François Joseph de Rochechouart, bishop of Laon and ambassador to the
Holy See. Though we can only speculate, Barbault appears to have retained no
rights over the books itself, having sold the plates outright to these
publishers. The publishers may therefore have commissioned the work, or have
agreed to publish it for their mutual benefit. Capitalizing on the eighteenth
century fashion for large Roman vedute, made possible by Piranesi and Vasi,
they may have agreed to print his plates to both make a profit themselves and
help rescue Barbault from his financial troubles. They were indeed able to
profit from the book. A posthumous edition was made in 1770, along with
abridged editions in 1787 and 1783. There was also a German edition of this
work, printed in Augsburg in 1782 by C.H. Stage. Barbault’s other major work,
_Les Plus beaux édifices de la Rome modern_ was much less successful by
comparison.

### References:

Barbault, Jean *Oxford Online Dictionary*. 15 Dec. 2011. Web

## Antonio Bosio, *Roma Sotteranea*

The first edition of Antonio Bosio’s *Roma sotterranea* was released
posthumously in 1634, approximately five years after the author’s death. Bosio
had conducted a vast amount of preparatory work and many Roman scholars were
looking forward to the publication of his ambitious project. After the
author’s death, the Knights of Malta, who were appointed as his beneficiary
(legatee), entrusted the Oratorian Giovanni Severani with the editing and
revising of Bosio’s work. Only the second part of Bosio’s original plan was
completed before the author’s death. This section of the project included two
parts: the first was devoted to early Christian burial practices and funeral
rituals and the second was dedicated to a detailed description of the Roman
catacombs that Bosio had explored. Cod. 31 of the Biblioteca Vallicelliana in
Rome contains Bosio’s original manuscript with Severani’s editorial revisions.
Among Severani’s additions, the most conspicuous was a whole fourth book on
the catacombs’ iconography. Facciotti printed the book and the printing
process lasted almost three years, partially due to the laborious work for the
many illustrations present in the book. The first edition of *Roma sotterranea
opera postuma di Antonio Bosio romano* [Subterranean Rome, a posthumous work
of the Roman Antonio Bosio] became the object of polemical disputes between
Catholics and Protestants on the history and customs of the early Christians.
The Brown University copy of Bosio’s book digitized for this website is a 1650
edition of the *Roma sotterranea*. Reprinted by Lodovico Grignani on the
occasion of the 1650 jubilee, this edition reached a greater number of readers
than the Facciotti edition. It was also known as *Il Bosietto*, [the little
Bosio], because of its compact format and reduced number of illustrations. The
book includes convenient summaries all around the text margins and only one
plate appears to be missing between page 124 and 125.

### References

Ghilardi, Massimiliano, “Baronio e la *Roma sotterranea* tra pietà oratoriana
e interessi gesuitici.” Luigi Giulia (ed.), *Baronio e le sue fonti: atti del
convegno internazionale di studi: Sora, 10-13 ottobre 2007*. Sora: Centro di
Studi sorani “Vincenzo Patriarca,” 2009. Print.

Parise, Nicola. “Bosio, Antonio.” *Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani.* Vol.
13 (1971). Istituto dell’enciclopedia italiana. Web.

## Giacomo Lauro, *Antiquae Urbis Splendor*

**Long title:** *Antiquae urbis splendor, hoc est praecipua eiusdum templa, amphitheatra, theatra, circi, naumachie, arcus triumphales, mausolea aliaque sumptuosiora aedificia, pompae item triumphalis et colossaearum imaginum descriptio; opera & industria Iacobi Lauri Romani in aes incisa atque in lucem edita. Addita est breuis quaedam et succincta imaginum explicatio in qua regum consulum imperatoruq; res gestae et rei romanae origo progressus incrementum, ac finis cu almae urbis antiquor. ac modernor. vestigior. additione utcunq; hoc insequenti anno 1630 reperiutur, et ex veteru ac recentior. historiar. monumentis clare ostenditur.*

The copy of Giacomo Lauro’s *Antiquae Urbis Splendor…* in the Theater that was
Rome Collection was most likely the edition printed in 1937 by Vitale
Mascardi, the first version of the book to have pages numbered through 167,
though in fact only 158 prints appear in this bound edition. The book has a
long and varied history of publishing, beginning in 1612, though Lauro’s work
on the book predates its publishing by at least eighteen years. The book was
first printed by Giacomo Mascardi, and it originally only contained two parts,
though by 1615 it had expanded to a third part. The first part contained 37
engravings, with a dedication to King Sigismund III of Poland, dated 1614, and
a portrait dated 1609 (borrowed from another book of engravings). The second
part contained a portrait of Charles Emmanuel I, Duke of Savoy, dated 1613,
and 41 engravings. It is worth noting that these first two books were both
dedicated to Polish nobility, probably due to the fact that Lauro had enjoyed
patronage from engraving Polish battles early in his career. The third part,
added later, was dedicated to Ranuccio Farnese, one of Lauro’s greater patrons
later in his life, and contained 40 engravings.

The number of plates included in each of the earlier editions of Lauro’s work
(printed at the Camera Apostolica in 1614 in four parts, and printed there
again in 1621 in three parts) was finally settled in 1628 with the addition of
the fourth and final book for a total of 166 engravings, which is the
generally accepted number for how many engravings total Lauro produced for
this work. The edition published by Vitale Mascardi and curated by Giovanni
Alto was released in 1637. Alto added a final index and numbered each of the
engravings, 2-167, for this latest release.

Here, accounts differ. An edition was published by Andrea Fei with the Latin
inscriptions at the bottom of nearly every engraving translated into Italian,
German, and French for the jubilee. Some sources list this edition as being
printed in 1641 others 1625. The recorded year of the jubilee was 1625 under
Pope Urban VIII (whose portrait also appears in the opening pages to book one
of *Antiquae Urbis Splendor*), however sources also seem to agree that the
jubilee book contained all four parts, which were not printed until 1628.
Editions were certainly published in the years 1625, 1630, 1641, and 1699, by
any account.

The edition in the Theater that was Rome collection is most likely later than
1637, though it is listed under that date. After 1637, when Giovanni Alto
carefully numbered and collected all of Lauro’s engravings, the later editions
were printed with engravings rearranged or removed, as seems to be the case in
this particular book. The unnumbered title page, dated 1612, is listed as page
1 in the index. The dedication portrait to Pope Urban VIII is numbered with
the date of the beginning of his papacy, 1623. This is followed by a letter to
the reader, written by Giovanni Alto and dated 1632. Next is the dedication to
Sigismund III, followed by a portrait of the king dated 1609. Part one of this
edition is then missing pages 5, 8, 11, 16, 20, and 38, some of which are
available in the widely published modern edition of the book, *Meraviglie
Della Roma Antica*. A listing for the 1637 edition mentions that there is an
additional dedication between pages 12 and 13, dated 1637, which is also
absent from this digitized version. In total, there are 44 engravings in part
one of this book.

The second book begins on numbered page 49, called “Antiquities of the City”
and dated 1613. The dedication to the Duke of Savoy, also dated 1613, is on
the next page, followed by a portrait. Part two contains 33 engravings total
(including the title, dedication, and portrait), though it is also missing
pages, specifically pages 60, 67, and 83.

The third book begins on the 85th engraving with a dedication to the Duke of
Parma and Piacenza, Ranuccio Farnese. No engravings are missing from this
part, which contains 42 engravings including the title page. The book contains
a number of garden views.

The fourth and final part explores modern views of the city, including
revisiting some of the buildings that Lauro had reconstructed in earlier parts
of the book, depicting them in a more ruinous state. The book begins on the
127th engraving with another dedication to the Duke of Savoy. It contains 40
engravings, including the final index, and is only missing one of the
engravings (131).

This particular edition contains a total of 158 engravings, somewhat less than
the anticipated 167. However, it does show some evidence of being rebound or
rearranged. In particular, the inverse of the page with the dedication to Pope
Urban VIII maintains the imprint of ink from a page that does not match up
with the actual facing page. The same is true of the back of the title page.
This may mean that the book was at one point bound in a different order, or
could be the remnants of stacking pages in the print shop. The pages
themselves are thick, and the first four blank pages each contain a watermark.
The first and second pages have a simple crown, while the third page has a
more complicated image – a beautiful fleur de lys embedded in a crowned crest.
The fourth page has a very simple symbol, a ‘P’ combined with an ‘L.’ All of
the engravings themselves were clearly done by hand, and as a result have a
very personal effect, evinced by Lauro’s handwritten inscriptions, which often
contain shorthand notations, even corrected mistakes in some places (for
instance, in the title page, the word ‘_succincta_’ was clearly initially
missing the final c, which was then scratched in above the word as an insert).

### References

Rossetti, Sergio. *Rome: A Bibliography.* Vol. 3. Florence, Italy: L.S.
Olschki, 2000. 39-40. Print.

Buckley, Penny. *The Splendors of Ancient Rome: A Seventeenth Century View.
The Splendors of Ancient Rome.* J. Paul Getty Museum, 1974. Print.

Cametti, Cecilia. Introduction. *Meraviglie Della Roma Antica* By Giacomo
Lauro and Cristina Falcucci. Roma: D. Audino, 1992. Print.

Di Calisto, Laura. "Lauro, Giacomo." *Dizionario Biografico Degli Italiani*_
Vol. 64. 2005. _Treccani_. Web. [[http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/giacomo-
lauro_(Dizionario-Biografico)/](http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/giacomo-
lauro_(Dizionario-Biografico)/)].

## *Il Campo Marzio dell'antica Roma opera di G.B. Piranesi socio della real Società degli antiquari di Londra*

## The Campus Martius of ancient Rome, the work of G.B. Piranesi, Fellow of the Royal Society of Antiquaries, London

Although Il Campo Marzio was published in 1762, its publication is announced
as part of the first volume of *Antichita Romane* (1756). Instead, after
Piranesi’s contact with Scottish Architect Robert Adam, who was studying in
Rome during the 1750’s, Piranesi began to work on a grand plan reconstructing
Imperial Rome. This large Plan of Campo Marzio in six copperplates was titled,
“Ichnographia,” or plan of the Campus Martius. As he collaborated with Robert
Adam, Piranesi became more enthused about the idea of creating a full-scale
treatise. Further, before Adam left Rome he had convinced Piranesi to set his
mind to the task, and Piranesi thanked Adam for his inspiration by dedicating
the work to him. The book is dedicated in 1757, even though it was published
in 1762. The *approbatio* is dated 1761.

The Campus Martius, or Field of Mars, is both an important investigation of
the archaeological history of the region, as well as an important phase of
Piranesi’s development as an artist. In this book, Piranesi investigates the
growth of the area on the left bank of the Tiber that was originally a parade
and sports ground. However, early imperial times gave rise to the construction
of many baths, theaters, and temples that began to cover the region contained
by the Capitoline, Quirinal, and Pincian Hills. In 37 plates, Piranesi
reconstructed the 18th-century Campus Martius as a field for his artistic
development of ancient Rome.. These architectural plans were not solely
prepared from Piranesi’s creative imagination, but rather emerged as a learned
assemblage from balancing his knowledge of the historical evidence and
obsessive accumulation of material and historical data.. Piranesi communicates
the depth of his knowledge in each commentary accompanying every Veduta. His
archaeological evidence is transformed into the forms of image and text.

In this treatise, mainly of vedute, Piranesi recreated some of the most
prominent buildings and bridges with modern reconstructions removed from view
so strikingly that the frame of decay of antiquity became believable. Piranesi
also went further in his investigation as he attempted to reconstruct areas of
his *Ichnographia* by creating three bird’s eye view vedute of what he
imagined the magnificence of Rome to look like. In these three views Piranesi
envisions three popular areas in ancient Rome including the Theater of Balbus
and theater of Marcellus, the Amphitheater of Statilis Taurus, and the
Pantheon. However, Piranesi does not just focus on the main buildings in the
neighborhood, but also every detail of the buildings, people, streets, and
waterways in the vicinity. With the completion of a book such as Il Campo
Marzio and the competitive nature of Roman print culture during the Grand Tour
era, Piranesi was a major contributor to the movement which made 18th century
Rome popular.

There are two versions of Il Campo Marzio. The first version was published in
Rome in 1762. This version is composed of two title pages, one in Latin and
one in Italian, two ornamented letters, one “A” in Latin and one “D” in
Italian, four vignettes, which in this particular book are located at the end
rather than the beginning where they are recorded more commonly, 42 plates by
Piranesi, 5 of these plates are composed of several copper plates, one
engraving by Westerhout pertaining to the raising of the Column of Antoninus
Pius in 1705, 68 pages of text in Italian and Latin, with six pages of
dedication to Robert Adam, and finally, 29 pages of indices. The second
version was published in Paris. These editions were published after 1762 and
contain plates numbered 418 to 455.

Il Campo Marzio is a large book meant for public display and open viewing. The
book is large enough to be laid open across a wide and tall surface. The pages
of the book are thin and soft, and upon further investigation it will be
determined if there exist any herbs for preservation purposes stuffed between
the pages. The book is currently bound, well-taken care of and in good
condition. It currently resides in Chicago within the collection of Mr.
Vincent Buonanno.

### References:

Penny, Nicholas. *Piranesi.* London: Oresko. (1978). Print.

Wilton-Ely, *John Giovanni Battista Piranesi: The Complete Etchings.* Vol. II.
San Francisco: Alan Wofsy Fine Arts. (1994). Print.

Wofsy, Alan. *Giovanni Battista Piranesi: The Complete Etchings*. Koln; New
York: Taschen. (2000): 394-431. Print.
